segments.text: Now, uh, you know, along this line of government limitations upon on the development portion, was Sea Grant a good idea or a bad idea?
Well, I—perhaps it's too early, really, to tell.
There seems to be, uh, there seems to be no question about land grant as being beneficial, but probably
three or four years after it started, it didn't look like it was going to be successful.
But I can conceive of Sea Grant being equally successful.
In fact, I just finished a little small study, one that
where I needed a couple months of work by somebody, and it funded that.
Total amount, though, for a couple months of work, counting overhead and everything else, nothing for me.
It was a couple thousand dollars, so it's not very... None of the government things seem very cost-effective.
But at least a lot of things get done that are worthwhile, I think.
I would think that in another ten years we can look back at Sea Grant and
and see whether it's cost-effective or not, probably.
There seems to be a move on the part of government to concentrate almost all funding agencies for oceanography under one central head.
Probably the Department of Commerce.
Do you favor that?
No.
It's the Russian system.
The Russian system, funding is organized bureaucratically.
And if you have a good idea,
funding agency doesn't like it, you're dead.
With several funding agencies, then you may find more people, somebody else who realizes this may be an important idea.
I'd rather have several competitive.
The congressmen tend to think that you should, for efficiency, have everything going out of one channel, but they haven't recognized that
that they could do the same thing with automobiles, require only one automobile, no choice in that.
And they fail to recognize that monopolies are not very efficient.
Witness the post office, the rail transport, the Social Security, above all else, the TVA, you add them all up.
They pay no taxes, but they're always getting their deficits filled.
Okay.
Now, the next several questions, the last several questions I have to ask you,
concern really the environment and the ocean.
What's your reaction to the environment movement?
Soft-headed.
The people who complain the most about the environment really don't think the problem through.
They're against everything.
I never hear them in favor of anything.
For example, they're against oil.
because of the oil spills.
They're against the offshore drilling here, failing to recognize that the offshore drilling has very minor spills.
In fact, to put it in a positive way, 99.98% of the oil that's produced offshore comes to shore in the pipeline.
That's a pretty high efficiency, higher purity than ivory soap.
In contrast,
If it isn't produced offshore, it's brought in by tankers, and the losses are very much greater than tankers.
The Argo merchant here spilled oil.
He came from the Caribbean and came all the way up here to spill it.
Saudi Arabia, oil was spilled at Cornwall in England, where oil will never be produced.
So the environmentalists ought to be pushing for offshore drilling if they want to preserve their environment.
The environmentalists are against burning coal
and they're against strip mining.
If they mine the coal from underground, their fatalities are orders in magnitude higher than the fatalities and injuries from strip mining.
They object to the strip mining because it spoils the scenery.
They've never, if you ask the environmentalists, they probably have never been out to Wyoming, Montana, in the remote areas where they...
where the cold is the thickest and the overburden the thinnest.
They're against nuclear energy.
There are good reasons to be against nuclear energy, but there are good reasons to be against all of the other things.

They are in favor of solar energy, but most of them don't know enough arithmetic or have enough interest in it to go through the necessary arithmetic to show that in no way is it cost-effective, several times more than any other source.
They're in favor of wave power.
Capital investment for wave power is so large that the interest on that exceeds the value of the energy it's got.
Wave energy, of course, is the same thing.
Thermal energy from the ocean isn't unknown.
It doesn't look like it's very large.
Wind power sounds fine, to go through the arithmetic.
I want to put in a well in my backyard with a windmill on it.
I find that...
It would cost over $800 to make the well, at least $500 for the windmill.
I figure I can get the investment back in about several hundred years.
These are things that the environmentalists just don't look at.
Now, I don't know anything the environmentalists are for.
They don't provide an alternative, and that's important.
Can't get away from the automobile and go to horse and buggy days.
A horse requires an acre of land to be fed.
There's not that many acres to take out of production for things that the humans need to feed the horses to the equivalent power.
I'm sorry it's that way.
I wish the environmentalists were more knowledgeable so that they could be a help instead of a problem.
They're part of the problem.
And there seems to be no way of changing them.
Mostly they're
I guess many of them are sociologists or type-oriented.
Maybe they're doing the term papers or something, but they don't know.
They don't try to go through the arithmetic themselves.
That's my opinion.
Then the issue of ocean pollution, since you've always been involved in sediments and those kinds of things, do you consider that dangerous?
No.
The only place where the pollution...
as dangerous as in enclosed bays, such as Buzzards Bay here, the oil spill is here, or in some other bays.
In fact, there are lots of bays in Louisiana, as you know.
But the damage from attributed oil spill there is negligible compared to the damage from a hurricane.
Absolutely negligible.
The oil that's lost in the ocean every year is so small it'd make a layer eight one-thousandths of a micron thick.

if it were spreading that is not spreading if you took all the oil that exists that hasn't been recovered the estimated resources anyway and dumped it on the ocean all it wanted to make a layer one millimeter thick there's no way the ocean is going to be changed into an ocean of oil no way now to carry this a little bit farther i saw when i'm out to sea i look for tar balls and have the
The crew, helmsmen, people on the bridge also keep a record.
They don't find enough to bother with, but we found a couple of them, and both of these are ones where
Gulf Africa, that is.
Both these are ones where I picked up a dip net to put some in a bucket to bring it back here to see whether it was tank washings or natural.
It turned out to be tank washings.
But the main thing of interest there is that all the little tar lumps are covered with or contained.
The young tar lumps don't have much, but the older ones that are hard have hydroids and barnacles growing on them, other things.
Eventually they make so much weight they make the thing sink.
In addition, these tarballs, clusters of them, serve as shelter for little triggerfish that are the same size and shape and color as the tarballs, much like sargassum fish hides under sargassum.
Triggerfish I didn't think was a deep-sea fish, but here they're taking advantage of an opportunity.
So it seems clear.
that there's a good possibility that the tar balls have increased the biomass of the ocean instead of decreased it.
Now, the tar and the oil is an organic product.
One can think of it as organic matter, a return to organic matter, food for the bacteria.
Zobel's whole life work has been learning that bacteria can destroy, can destroy, he's credited for
finding how bacteria help make oil, but that's not the case.
Mostly it's how it destroys them.
Now, this means that...
It's getting worse, I guess.
This means, of course, that the bacteria, a little oil may be very helpful, may be desirable for the bacteria or the organisms.
You can have too much.
Even oxygen is a pollutant when it's too abundant.
It kills the animal too much, if you have too much oxygen.
Trace metals that are present in it are considered very bad, but on the other hand, trace metals are necessary for agriculture on land, probably also on the ocean.
The bad oil spills have been those with refined oil, refined oil, heavy oil.
It doesn't evaporate very fast.
Whereas crude oil, 3 quarters of it evaporates in two or three days.
The ones confined in marshes and so forth, then of course, it is picked up by various animals in the marsh.
And the presence of trace elements, of course,
Some of the trace elements are considered carcinogens, because a rat fed on them will die if he gets on a foot, for example.
Extrapolating for the soft drink sweeteners, you'd be killed if you drank 300 bottles of Coke every day for the rest of your life.
Not that thing.
But there's a law that says if they exhibit any cars to affect them, they should be banned.
In fact, the same bureau says give standards for discharge of water to the ocean.
You're not allowed to let the Mississippi River discharge the ocean.
Is there anything else you'd like to add to the tape?
No, I don't think so.
Okay.
I thank you then.
